Summary: The proposal aims to develop a geometry-adaptive framework for deep learning across Euclidean and non-Euclidean domains, combining spectral graph theory, attention mechanisms, and differential geometry to address limitations of current GNNs (e.g., over-smoothing, scalability). The method includes geometry-aware message passing, hierarchical pooling, and unified embedding spaces. Experiments span synthetic benchmarks, real-world tasks, scalability, and cross-geometry generalization.
Strengths: Clear and well-motivated problem statement highlighting limitations of current GNNs.
Ambitious and theoretically grounded hypothesis leveraging geometric priors.
Innovative combination of spectral methods, attention mechanisms, and differential geometry.
Comprehensive experiment plan with synthetic and real-world benchmarks, dynamic graphs, and cross-geometry generalization.
Includes ablation studies to isolate contributions of key components.
Weaknesses: Limited discussion of computational feasibility for dynamic/large-scale graphs.
Integration of spectral filters, attention, and differential geometry lacks technical detail.
No explicit mention of baseline comparisons for cross-geometry generalization.
Validation plan could benefit from more emphasis on failure modes and edge cases.
Proposed method is ambitious but may face practical implementation hurdles.
Questions: How will computational costs be managed for dynamic/large-scale graphs and hybrid embedding spaces?
What are the theoretical guarantees for the proposed geometry-adaptive framework?
How will the hybrid embedding spaces (Euclidean, hyperbolic, spherical) be practically integrated?
What specific strategies are in place to ensure scalability in dynamic graphs?
Can you provide more details on potential failure modes and edge cases in your validation plan?
Limitations: Potential computational overhead from combining spectral filters and attention.
Unclear how dynamic graph updates will be handled efficiently.
Risk of over-engineering the framework for niche geometries.
Generalization to unseen geometries may be challenging.
Scalability may be limited by memory constraints in billion-edge networks.
